title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement [INSERT CONTACT METHOD]. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct

title: Contributing to UMI4Cats
text: can fix typos, spelling mistakes, grammatical errors documentation directly using GitHub web interface, long changes made source file. generally means ’ll need edit roxygen2 comments .R, .Rd file. can find .R file generates .Rd reading comment first line.

title: Contributing to UMI4Cats
text: want make bigger change, ’s good idea first file issue make sure someone team agrees ’s needed. ’ve found bug, please file issue illustrates bug minimal reprex (also help write unit test, needed). Install development dependences devtools::install_dev_deps(), make sure package passes R CMD check running devtools::check(). R CMD check doesn’t pass cleanly, ’s good idea ask help continuing. Create Git branch pull request (PR). recommend using usethis::pr_init("brief-description--change"). Make changes, commit git, create PR running usethis::pr_push(), following prompts browser. title PR briefly describe change. body PR contain Fixes #issue-number. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md (.e. just first header). Follow style described https://style.tidyverse.org/news.html.
code: ### Pull request process         *   Fork the package and clone onto your computer. If you haven't done this before, we recommend using `usethis::create_from_github("", fork = TRUE)`.

title: Contributing to UMI4Cats
text: New code follow tidyverse style guide. can use styler package apply styles, please don’t restyle code nothing PR.
code: *  We use [roxygen2](https://cran.r-project.org/package=roxygen2), with [Markdown syntax](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/roxygen2/vignettes/rd-formatting.html), for documentation.   *  We use [testthat](https://cran.r-project.org/package=testthat) for unit tests.  Contributions with test cases included are easier to accept.   ## Code of Conduct   Please note that the UMI4Cats project is released with a  [Contributor Code of Conduct](CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md). By contributing to this  project you agree to abide by its terms.

title: Getting help with SPICEY
text: Start making minimal reproducible example using reprex package. haven’t heard used reprex , ’re treat! Seriously, reprex make R-question-asking endeavors easier (pretty insane ROI five ten minutes ’ll take learn ’s ). additional reprex pointers, check Get help! section tidyverse site.

title: Getting help with SPICEY
text: Armed reprex, next step figure ask. See also Bioconductor help website. ’s bug: ’re right place, file issue. ’re sure: let community help figure ! problem bug feature request, can easily return report . default, search pre-populated :issue :open. can edit qualifiers (e.g. :pr, :closed) needed. example, ’d simply remove :open search issues repo, open closed. makes development efficient avoids expensive context switching problems, cost taking longer get back . process makes good reprex particularly important might multiple months initial report start working . can’t reproduce bug, can’t fix !
code: *   If it's a question: start with [community.rstudio.com](https://community.rstudio.com/), and/or StackOverflow. If this a Bioconductor-related question, please ask it at the [Bioconductor Support Website](https://support.bioconductor.org/) using the [appropriate package tag](https://support.bioconductor.org/t/SPICEY) (the website will send an automatic email to the package authors). There are more people there to answer questions. Before opening a new issue, be sure to [search issues and pull requests](https://github.com//issues) to make sure the bug hasn't been reported and/or already fixed in the development version. ## What happens next?                                                                To be as efficient as possible, development of tidyverse packages tends to be very bursty, so you shouldn't worry if you don't get an immediate response.                                                               Typically we don't look at a repo until a sufficient quantity of issues accumulates, then there’s a burst of intense activity as we focus our efforts.

title: Measuring tissue specificity from single cell data with SPICEY
text: SPICEY R package designed infer cell type specificity single-cell omics data. supports input widely used frameworks Seurat (single-cell RNA-seq) Signac (single-cell ATAC-seq), computes metrics cell-type specificity regulatory transcriptional levels.

title: Measuring tissue specificity from single cell data with SPICEY
text: SPICEY designed operate results differential analyses performed either single-cell ATAC-seq (chromatin accessibility) single-cell RNA-seq (gene expression) data. analyses compare feature—either regulatory element (e.g., peak) gene—across cell types identify cell-type-specific activity expression. SPICEY takes advantage resulting statistics, specifically log2 fold-change associated adjusted p-values, reflect magnitude statistical confidence differential activity. leveraging pre-computed differential results, SPICEY quantifies cell-type specificity composite metrics capture strength selectivity feature enrichment individual cell types.

what: Cell-Type Specificity Indices: RETSI and GETSI
title: Measuring tissue specificity from single cell data with SPICEY
text: SPICEY introduces two complementary metrics: RETSI (Regulatory Element Tissue Specificity Index): Quantifies cell-type specificity regulatory regions cell types (e.g., ATAC-seq peaks). GETSI (Gene Expression Tissue Specificity Index): Quantifies specificity gene expression across distinct cell types. RETSI GETSI calculated using weighted specificity score feature (regulatory region gene), defined : TSIi,x=FCi,xmax(FC)x⋅wi,x TSI_{,x} = \frac{FC_{,x}}{\max(FC)_x} \cdot w_{,x} wi,x=rescale(−log10(padji,x),[0,1]) w_{,x} = \text{rescale}\left( -\log_{10}(padj_{,x}),\ [0, 1] \right) : ii specific cell type x∈{r,g}x \\{r, g\}, rr regulatory region (RETSI) gg gene (GETSI) FCi,x\text{FC}_{,x} log fold-change feature xx cell type ii wi,xw_{,x} weight term, defined rescaled value −log10(adjusted p-value)-\log_{10}(\text{adjusted } p\text{-value}) 0 1 Additionally, SPICEY supports integration regulatory elements putative target genes using multiple linking strategies, including: Nearest-gene assignment Co-accessibility-based linking (co-accessibility links available) linking approaches enable SPICEY combine regulatory specificity (RETSI) gene expression specificity (GETSI), facilitating integrated analyses gene regulatory architecture single-cell resolution. vignette demonstrates use SPICEY preprocessed GRanges input files. input files must prepared advance (provided package).

title: Measuring tissue specificity from single cell data with SPICEY
text: complement fold change-based indices, SPICEY also quantifies distributional skewness features using Shannon entropy. regulatory region gene, activity expression values across NNN cell types converted probability distribution: H=−∑=1Npilog2(pi) H = - \sum_{=1}^{N} p_i \log_2(p_i) Hnorm=1−eH H_{norm} = 1 - e^{H} : pi,x=ai,x∑j=1Naj,xp_{,x} = \frac{a_{,x}}{\sum_{j=1}^{N} a_{j,x}} normalized activity expression feature xx across NN cell types ai,xa_{,x} activity (RETSI) expression (GETSI) value cell type $$ HxH_x Shannon entropy, Normalized Entropy ranges 0 (cell type specific) 1 (cell type shared).

title: Measuring tissue specificity from single cell data with SPICEY
text: Install development version GitHub:

title: Measuring tissue specificity from single cell data with SPICEY
text: SPICEY requires carefully prepared input files representing processed single-cell omics data, specifically differential analyses chromatin accessibility (ATAC-seq) /gene expression (RNA-seq). inputs provided within package must generated externally beforehand. detailed description required input necessary metadata.

title: Measuring tissue specificity from single cell data with SPICEY
text: Format: GRanges data.frame convertible GRanges Required columns: seqnames, start, end — genomic coordinates peak. avg_log2FC — average log2 fold-change chromatin accessibility peak specific cell type (output differential accessibility analysis). p_val — raw adjusted p-value corresponding differential accessibility test peak (output differential accessibility analysis). cell_type — cell type cluster label associated differential measurement. Optional columns: annotation — genomic annotation peak (e.g., promoter, enhancer) distanceToTSS — distance peak nearest transcription start site. nearest_gene — gene symbol/name closest gene peak. Required linking regulatory elements based nearest gene. ATAC peaks input must include multiple rows per peak representing differential statistics cell type. example, peak may appear different avg_log2FC, p_val, cell_type values reflecting differential accessibility cell type.

title: Measuring tissue specificity from single cell data with SPICEY
text: Format: GRanges data.frame convertible GRanges Required columns: seqnames, start, end — genomic coordinates gene avg_log2FC — average log2 fold-change chromatin accessibility peak specific cell type (output differential accessibility analysis). p_val — raw adjusted p-value corresponding differential accessibility test peak (output differential accessibility analysis). cell_type — cell type cluster label associated differential measurement. Optional columns: symbol — identifier gene (official gene symbol). Required linking regulatory elements based nearest gene. RNA input must represent differential expression results, .e., statistics computed gene across cell types.

what: 3. Co-accessibility Links (optional, for region to gene linking mode)
title: Measuring tissue specificity from single cell data with SPICEY
text: Purpose: link regulatory elements based co-accessibility inferred tools like Signac’s LinkPeaks(). supports integrative analysis regulatory elements gene expression. Format: Either GInteractions GRangesList object metadata columns. Required columns: Peaks1 — genomic coordinate ID first peak pair. Peaks2 — genomic coordinate ID second peak linked co-accessibility. coaccess — co-accessibility score correlation value. CCAN1, CCAN2 — CCAN (co-accessibility network) identifiers peaks. peaks referenced must match exactly ATAC peaks input (coordinates peak IDs).

title: Measuring tissue specificity from single cell data with SPICEY
text: demonstrate use SPICEY prepared input files (explained previous sections).

code: # Filter links for high coaccessibility score coacc_links <- cicero_links |>    dplyr::filter(coaccess > 0.5)  # Annotate links with CCANs and filter for Promoter-Distal interactions links <- annotate_links_with_ccans(   links = coacc_links,   coaccess_cutoff_override = 0.25,   filter_promoter_distal = TRUE,   txdb = TxDb.Hsapiens.UCSC.hg38.knownGene::TxDb.Hsapiens.UCSC.hg38.knownGene)  retsi_gene_coacc <- annotate_with_coaccessibility(   re = retsi,   links = links,   txdb = TxDb.Hsapiens.UCSC.hg38.knownGene::TxDb.Hsapiens.UCSC.hg38.knownGene,   name_links = "HPAP") #> GRanges title: Measuring tissue specificity from single cell data with SPICEY
text: step SPICEY workflow—computing RETSI, GETSI, performing linking methods—can run independently using respective functions (described previous sections), also developed convenient wrapper function run_spicey() streamlines entire analysis single call, automatically handling necessary computations based input data provided. approach especially useful users want execute full pipeline straightforward reproducible manner, without manually managing intermediate step. accepts ATAC /RNA differential analysis results data input, optionally linking method (“nearest” “coaccessibility”) along required additional inputs (e.g., links coaccessibility). Depending data parameters supplied, function dynamically performs: RETSI calculation (ATAC data provided). GETSI calculation (RNA data provided). Linking regulatory elements target genes (data types linking method provided). returning intermediate final results structured list, wrapper allows users easily access inspect step’s output desired. users prefer detailed control tracking step, running component functions separately remains fully supported encouraged. Arguments atac : GRanges object data frame convertible GRanges containing differential accessibility results scATAC-seq data. Required columns: seqnames, start, end: Genomic coordinates peaks avg_log2FC: Average log2 fold-change accessibility peak p_val: Raw adjusted p-value differential accessibility tests cell_type: Cell type cluster label rna: GRanges object data frame convertible GRanges containing differential expression results scRNA-seq data. Required columns similar atac relevant gene expression. seqnames, start, end: Genomic coordinates peaks avg_log2FC: Average log2 fold-change accessibility peak p_val: Raw adjusted p-value differential accessibility tests cell_type: Cell type cluster label link_method: Character string specifying linking method regulatory elements (REs) target genes. Options : "nearest" (default): Links REs nearest gene "coaccessibility": Uses co-accessibility links assign target genes links: Required link_method = "coaccessibility". data frame GRangesList containing co-accessibility links scores peak pairs. coaccess_cutoff_override (default: 0.25): Numeric value filter co-accessibility links minimum co-accessibility score. Links threshold filtered . filter_promoter_distal (default: TRUE): Logical indicating whether keep promoter-distal interactions filtering co-accessibility links.
code: # Compute GETSI  results <- run_spicey(rna = rna)  # Compute RETSI results <- run_spicey(atac=atac)  # Compute GETSI + RETSI results <- run_spicey(atac=atac, rna=rna)  # Compute GETSI + RETSI and link RE to target genes through nearest gene method results <- run_spicey(rna = rna, atac=atac, link_method = "nearest")  # Compute GETSI + RETSI and link RE to target genes through coaccessibility method results <- run_spicey(   atac = atac_data,   rna = rna_data,   link_method = "coaccessibility",   links = coaccessibility_links,   coaccess_cutoff_override = 0.25,     filter_promoter_distal = TRUE     )

title: Measuring tissue specificity from single cell data with SPICEY
text: following output GRanges object containing genomic regions (ranges), representing regulatory element (e.g., enhancer promoter) annotated multiple metadata columns. columns provide statistical, biological, functional information derived chromatin accessibility gene expression data.

title: Measuring tissue specificity from single cell data with SPICEY
text: annotated GRanges object thus serves comprehensive resource combining genomic location, cell type-specific accessibility, gene linkage, expression specificity — facilitating downstream functional genomics analyses.

title: Authors and Citation

title: Authors and Citation
text: author1, author2, author3 (publicationYear) articleTitle, *journalName*; volumeNumber, [linkToPublication](linkToPublication)
code: @Article{,   entry = {Article},   title = {articleTitle},   author = {{author1} and {author2} and {author3}},   journal = {journalName},   year = {publicationYear},   volume = {volume},   number = {number},   pages = {pages},   url = {linkToPublication}, }

title: Calculates cell type specificity from single cell data
text: goal SPICEY provide user-friendly pipeline quantifying visualizing tissue specificity specificity

title: Calculates cell type specificity from single cell data
text: can install latest release SPICEY github repository: Now can load package using library(SPICEY).

title: Calculates cell type specificity from single cell data
text: detailed instructions use SPICEY, please see vignette.
code: library(SPICEY) # Compute GETSI  results <- run_spicey(rna = rna)  # Compute RETSI results <- run_spicey(atac=atac)  # Compute GETSI + RETSI results <- run_spicey(atac=atac, rna=rna)  # Compute GETSI + RETSI and link RE to target genes through nearest gene method results <- run_spicey(rna = rna, atac=atac, link_method = "nearest")  # Compute GETSI + RETSI and link RE to target genes through coaccessibility method results <- run_spicey(   atac = atac_data,   rna = rna_data,   link_method = "coaccessibility",   links = coaccessibility_links,   coaccess_cutoff_override = 0.25,  # default   filter_promoter_distal = TRUE     # default )

title: Calculates cell type specificity from single cell data
text: Please note SPICEY project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project, agree abide terms.

what: Annotate co-accessible links with CCAN membership and return GInteractions — annotate_links_with_ccans
title: Annotate co-accessible links with CCAN membership and return GInteractions — annotate_links_with_ccans
text: Annotate co-accessible links CCAN membership return GInteractions

title: Annotate co-accessible links with CCAN membership and return GInteractions — annotate_links_with_ccans
code: annotate_links_with_ccans(   links,   coaccess_cutoff_override = 0.25,   tolerance_digits = 2,   filter_promoter_distal = TRUE,   txdb = NULL )

title: Annotate co-accessible links with CCAN membership and return GInteractions — annotate_links_with_ccans
text: links data.frame co-accessibility links columns Peak1, Peak2, coaccess. coaccess_cutoff_override Numeric, coaccessibility cutoff CCAN generation (default 0.25). tolerance_digits Integer, rounding precision cutoff (default 2). filter_promoter_distal Logical, whether keep Promoter-Distal links (default TRUE). txdb TxDb object peak annotation (required filter_promoter_distal=TRUE).

title: Annotate co-accessible links with CCAN membership and return GInteractions — annotate_links_with_ccans
text: GInteractions object annotated coaccess, CCAN1, CCAN2 metadata columns.

title: Annotate regions with nearest gene and promoter information — annotate_with_nearest

what: Retrieve gene annotations from Ensembl via biomaRt — biomart_genes
title: Retrieve gene annotations from Ensembl via biomaRt — biomart_genes
text: Downloads gene annotation data Ensembl using biomaRt, processes , returns list data.frame filtered GRanges object containing protein-coding genes. useful RNA-seq epigenomic pipelines.

title: Retrieve gene annotations from Ensembl via biomaRt — biomart_genes
Retrieve gene annotations from Ensembl via biomaRt — biomart_genes

what: Annotate and Filter Gene Expression Differential Data, Return GRanges — combine_gex_da
title: Annotate and Filter Gene Expression Differential Data, Return GRanges — combine_gex_da
text: function takes named list gene expression differential analysis results (typically one data frame per cell type). maps gene symbols Ensembl IDs, joins genomic coordinates Biomart, filters protein-coding genes canonical chromosomes, converts GRanges object, adds cell_type metadata column based list name.

title: Annotate and Filter Gene Expression Differential Data, Return GRanges — combine_gex_da
Annotate and Filter Gene Expression Differential Data, Return GRanges — combine_gex_da
text: rna_da named list data frames, element corresponds cell type contains differential gene expression results. Row names gene symbols.

title: Annotate and Filter Gene Expression Differential Data, Return GRanges — combine_gex_da
text: single GRanges object combining annotated genes, metadata columns including differential statistics cell_type column.

title: Annotate and Filter Gene Expression Differential Data, Return GRanges — combine_gex_da

what: Link RETSI peaks with GETSI values from coaccessibility — link_spicey_coaccessible
title: Link RETSI peaks with GETSI values from coaccessibility — link_spicey_coaccessible
text: function combines GETSI (Gene Expression Tissue Specificity Index) data RETSI (Regulatory Element Tissue Specificity Index) results, matching gene symbols cell types. renames entropy columns, performs joins merge relevant annotations, resolves coordinate conflicts.

title: Link RETSI peaks with GETSI values from coaccessibility — link_spicey_coaccessible
Link RETSI peaks with GETSI values from coaccessibility — link_spicey_coaccessible
text: re data.frame tibble containing RETSI results least columns: genes_HPAP: gene symbols cell_type norm_entropy seqnames, start, end, annotation, distanceToTSS, region, RETSI getsi data.frame tibble containing GETSI results least columns: symbol: gene symbol cell_type GETSI norm_entropy seqnames, start, end

what: Run full SPICEY pipeline: compute RETSI and GETSI, annotate regulatory elements, and link measures — run_spicey
title: Run full SPICEY pipeline: compute RETSI and GETSI, annotate regulatory elements, and link measures — run_spicey
text: function performs complete SPICEY pipeline workflow: Computes Regulatory Element Tissue Specificity Index (RETSI) scATAC-seq differential accessibility results. Computes Gene Expression Tissue Specificity Index (GETSI) scRNA-seq differential expression results. Annotates regulatory elements (RE) nearest genes. Optionally annotates RE co-accessible target genes link_method = "coaccessibility". Links RETSI GETSI scores either nearest gene co-accessibility links.

title: Run full SPICEY pipeline: compute RETSI and GETSI, annotate regulatory elements, and link measures — run_spicey
code: run_spicey(   atac = NULL,   rna = NULL,   link_method = NULL,   links = NULL,   coaccess_cutoff_override = 0.25,   filter_promoter_distal = TRUE )

title: Run full SPICEY pipeline: compute RETSI and GETSI, annotate regulatory elements, and link measures — run_spicey
text: atac GRanges data.frame convertible GRanges containing differential accessibility results. Must include seqnames, start, end, avg_log2FC, p_val, cell_type columns. rna GRanges data.frame convertible GRanges containing differential expression results. Must include seqnames, start, end, avg_log2FC, p_val, cell_type columns. link_method Character string specifying linking method. One "nearest" "coaccessibility". NULL (default), linking performed. links Optional. data.frame GRangesList co-accessibility links. Required link_method = "coaccessibility". coaccess_cutoff_override Numeric scalar. Co-accessibility score cutoff used filter links. Default 0.25. filter_promoter_distal Logical. Whether filter links keep promoter-distal interactions using co-accessibility. Default TRUE.

title: Run full SPICEY pipeline: compute RETSI and GETSI, annotate regulatory elements, and link measures — run_spicey
text: list containing: retsi Data frame computed RETSI scores atac provided. getsi Data frame computed GETSI scores rna provided. linking Data frame linking RETSI GETSI scores link_method specified.

title: Run full SPICEY pipeline: compute RETSI and GETSI, annotate regulatory elements, and link measures — run_spicey
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Compute GETSI only results <- run_spicey_pipeline(rna = rna_data)  # Compute RETSI only results <- run_spicey_pipeline(atac = atac_data)  # Compute both GETSI and RETSI without linking results <- run_spicey_pipeline(atac = atac_data, rna = rna_data)  # Compute both and link with nearest gene method results <- run_spicey_pipeline(atac = atac_data, rna = rna_data, link_method = "nearest")  # Compute both and link with co-accessibility method results <- run_spicey_pipeline(   atac = atac_data,   rna = rna_data,   link_method = "coaccessibility",   links = coaccessibility_links,   coaccess_cutoff_override = 0.3,   filter_promoter_distal = TRUE ) } # }

title: Compute GETSI scores and entropy from RNA-seq data — spicey_getsi
text: GRanges object GETSI scores entropy values metadata columns.

title: Compute RETSI scores from a List of GRanges representing scATAC-seq peaks per cell type — spicey_retsi
